title: Cats. 7–8  Madame Matisse with Her Fan, 1906 • Nude in a Folding Chair, 1906
publication_title: Matisse Paintings, Works on Paper, Sculpture, and Textiles at the Art Institute of Chicago

<section class="osci-tk-epub-section tombstone" id="tombstone">Madame Matisse with Her Fan  
Paris, 1906  
Pen and black ink over graphite on cream wove paper; 49.4 × 31.2 cm (19 1/8 × 12 in.)  
Signed: Henri-Matisse (lower right, in pen and black ink)  
The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Dorothy Braude Edinburg to the Harry B. and Bessie K. Braude Memorial Collection, 1998.709

Nude in a Folding Chair  
Paris, c. 1906  
Brush and black wash on ivory laid paper, pieced; 66 × 47 cm (26 × 18 1/4 in.)  
Signed: Henri-Matisse (lower right, in pen and black ink)  
The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Mrs. Potter Palmer, II, 1944.576

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section curatorial_entry" id="curatorial_entry">In the drawings Madame Matisse with Her Fan and Nude in a Folding Chair, Henri Matisse used bold, gestural lines to depict his wife, Amélie (see fig. 7–8.1), who often acted as a model during the early years of her husband’s career. Just one year before, she sat for the artist’s striking portrait Woman with a Hat (1905; fig. 7–8.2), which he exhibited at the 1905 Salon d’Automne, where French critics christened Matisse and his circle “fauves,” or wild beasts, for their explorations of the evocative potential of color. Part of his continued investigations of expressive forms outside of naturalism, these drawings demonstrate his emerging concern with decoration and sumptuous patterns.

Madame Matisse with Her Fan relates to Matisse’s earlier paintings of his wife wearing the same Japanese gown, including The Terrace, Saint Tropez (1904; fig. 7–8.3), Madame Matisse in a Kimono (1905; fig. 7–8.4), and La japonaise: Woman beside the Water (summer 1905; fig. 7–8.5). In each work, the artist used flat, gestural lines and saturated colors to depict the patterned garment, which both gives a shape to the covered body and pushes the decorative motif to the surface. The artist’s friend and fellow Fauve André Derain depicted Matisse sketching Amélie in the kimono in Matisse and His Wife at Collioure (summer 1905; fig. 7–8.6) and also made his own painting of Matisse’s robed wife, Woman with a Shawl (1905; fig. 7–8.7). These works point to the importance of this decorative textile in Matisse’s investigations of expressive plastic and pictorial forms.

Both Madame Matisse with Her Fan and Nude in a Folding Chair bear the hallmarks of Matisse’s draftsmanship at this time. In the first, the off-center framing of Amélie, seated and wearing the same kimono, accentuates the angled depiction of the figure. Her disproportionately large left side and simplified oversized hand seem to project forward from the paper. Using multiple sizes of dip pens, the artist created tension between volume and surface by utilizing flat, heavy strokes for the patterned textile and the shadow beneath the chair. Finer lines and a pointed pen further exaggerate the depth and volume of the seated figure. For Nude in a Folding Chair, the artist first drew a faint outline to indicate the general character of the pose. He completed the portrait with quick, short strokes of black wash, pairing overlapping, bold, expressive hatchmarks with the blank paper to evoke the figure and the space of the room. Partway through the process, Matisse added a paper strip to the top of the drawing that accentuates the skewed perspective that seems to simultaneously offer both a frontal and overhead view of the figure.

The artist’s fascination with arresting, and often exotic, fabrics continued throughout his career (see cat. 34). While the recognizable kimono consumes the figure in Madame Matisse with Her Fan, Matisse used the common practice of laying a cloth beneath his seated model in Nude in a Folding Chair to explore the flattening effect of the design as it pushes against and surrounds the contours of her body. The stark contrast of negatives and positives defined within strong outlines in these drawings relates to Matisse’s contemporaneous woodcuts. The artist only explored the medium during this period in a brief investigation that may have been hastened by his interest in the possibilities of line and decoration.  
Brandon Ruud and Marin Sarvé-Tarr

Matisse met and married Amélie in 1898. On her importance to Matisse’s early work, see Hilary Spurling, The Unknown Matisse: A Life of Henri Matisse; The Early Years, 1869–1908 (Knopf, 1998).

Matisse also exhibited La japonaise at the 1905 Salon d’Automne. Derain made the gown the focus of his painting Woman with a Shawl (1905; fig. 7–8.7).

See Barr, Matisse, p. 98. See also Royal Academy of Arts, Matisse, His Art and His Textiles: The Fabric of Dreams, exh. cat. (Royal Academy of Arts, 2004), p. 181, cats. 7–8.
